awd_titl_txt: A Modeling Study of Easterly Waves and Their Intraseasonal Variability in the East Pacific
awd_abstract_narration:
Easterly waves (EWs) are wavelike atmospheric disturbances with a ridge-to-trough size of roughly 1,000km which propagate from east to west at low latitudes.  EWs are important weather makers in much of the tropics and play a critical role in hurricane development.  Much of the research has focused on African EWs, which along the easterly jet over the Sahel and propagate westward over the North Atlantic.  The genesis of these waves is often explained in terms of jet instabilities particular to the easterly jet, yet similar EWs are found in the tropical eastern Pacific where the large-scale flow characteristics are very different.  One explanation for the presence of EWs in the eastern equatorial Pacific is that they originated as African EWs, formed through processes associated with the African easterly jet, and subsequently propagated across the Atlantic and the Caribbean to reach the eastern Pacific.  While there is some evidence to support this theory, previous work by the PI (see AGS-1347738) suggests that EWs can form in the tropical eastern Pacific despite the clear differences between this region and the Sahel.

This project tests the hypothesis that east Pacific EWs are largely caused by upscale growth of topographically-generated disturbances downwind of the mountain ranges of Central America. Numerical simulation by the PI have shown that EW activity is dramatically reduced when the Central American topography is flattened, but these simulations were crude as the removal of topography has a variety of dramatic effects on the meteorology of the region including mean flow, cloudiness and precipitation.  Simulations to be performed here would use a "nudging" technique to constrain the background flow despite modifications to topography and other factors so that a more focused study of wave generation by specific forcing mechanisms can be performed in a realistic setting.  The work would use the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model in a convection-permitting configuration.  The work would also address the modulation of EWs by intraseasonal oscillations of the background flow.  Additional work uses diagnostic techniques including vorticity and energy budgets to study EW generation and propagation in observational data.

The work has societal relevance due to the key role of EWs in tropical meteorology and hurricane genesis.  If EWs found in the eastern Pacific originated in the African easterly jet they may be more predictable than if they are generated locally by Central American topography, thus the results of this work have potential implications for operational forecasting.  The modulation of EW activity by intraseasonal oscillations is also of practical interest given the long lead times of intraseasonal oscillations.  In addition, the project provides support and training for a graduate student, thereby providing for the future workforce in this research area.

Intellectual Merit: 

The overarching goal of this study was to understand the origin of east Pacific easterly waves. Easterly waves are rotating atmospheric circulations that are the precursor disturbances for hurricanes and tropical storms in the east Pacific and the Atlantic.  Understanding their origins has important implications for prediction of tropical cyclone activity that affects lives and property. Wind jets that blow into the Pacific through gaps in mountains, daily storms that form over the Central and South American mountains and move offshore, as well as large-scale atmospheric disturbances that move into the east Pacific from both the east and west have been hypothesized to affect the origins of east Pacific easterly waves. Our study used atmospheric models and observations to scrutinize easterly wave origins. We also examined the effect of climate change on easterly waves and the resulting implications for hurricane formation. 

Our major results are as follows: 

1) Observations were used to show that the wind jet that flows into the Pacific through the gap in the mountains between Costa Rica and Nicaragua has a strong influence on the formation of easterly waves by affecting atmospheric moisture and precipitation. The nature of influence of this wind jet on easterly waves is unique relative to other atmospheric disturbances. 

2) A regional atmospheric model was used to show that strong precipitation in easterly waves is a key factor in spinning up rotation in the waves, although the processes shown in the model differ in some ways from that suggested in observational datasets.  This discrepancy suggests that more observational and modeling work is needed to fine tune the exact mechanism behind how easterly waves spin up. 

3) Closing the Central American mountain gaps in an atmospheric model decreases the strength and number of easterly waves, consistent with #1 above. The easterly waves that do form tend to occur further away from the Central American coast. 

4) Climate change simulations with global models suggest that east Pacific easterly waves and tropical cyclones will get pushed southwest away from the Central American and Mexican Coasts in a warmer end-of-21st Century climate. While this might reduce the coastal damage caused by hurricanes, it would also potentially create water resource problems, as easterly waves and tropical cyclones produce a large fraction of annual precipitation in places like Mexico. 

Broader Impacts:

The project has forged understanding of the large-scale conditions favorable for hurricane activity in the east Pacific, given that easterly waves are the precursors to hurricanes. Easterly waves also provide a large fraction of rainfall over Central America and Mexico.  Therefore, this work has important consequences for the prediction and understanding of rainfall in this region that is important for agriculture and other interests. As mentioned above, we have also shown that a future warmer climate implies a weaker impact of easterly waves and hurricanes in Mexico and Central America. This is both good and bad. There may be fewer destructive storms, but also more stressors on water resources.  

Results from this work have already been integrated into the curriculum of a course at Colorado State University, ATS 742 (Tropical Meteorology). This grant has contributed to the education of graduate Justin Whitaker who completed his M.S. thesis under this project in Fall 2017, and his Ph.D dissertation in the Summer of 2021. Three undergraduate summer interns under a Research Experiences for Undergraduates program at Colorado State University were mentored on work related to this project, including two from underrepresented backgrounds.
